data.title: Table tennis score
data.solution:
playerA, playerB = input().split()
scores = [*map(int,input().split('-'))]

tot = sum(scores)
server_idx = (tot//2)%2 if min(scores)<10 else tot%2
server = [playerA, playerB][server_idx]
leader_is_server = scores[0]>=scores[1]
leader = [playerA, playerB][server_idx if leader_is_server else 1-server_idx]

if max(scores) >= 11 and max(scores) >= min(scores)+2:
    print(f"{leader} WON!!!")
    print("SET ENDED")
else:
    print("TIE" if scores[0]==scores[1] else f"LEADER IS {leader}")
    print(f"SERVER IS {server}")
data.statement:
Marc is passionate about table tennis... but he often gets distracted when watching a match. He needs a tool that lets him tell who's leading the current set and who's going to serve on the next shot... or if the set is over.

In table tennis, the serve alternates between players every <<two points>>. So, the first player serves twice (regardless of the score), then their opponent serves twice, and so on. The first player to <<11 points>> wins the set.
Be careful! If the players reach a score of 10-10, the serve alternates <<every point>>, and the winner is the first to be <<two points ahead>> of their opponent.

Regarding scoring, the score of the player <<who will serve next>> is always announced <<in front>>. If the set has already ended, this still applies: the first score announced is the score of the player who would serve next if the game were to continue.
For example, when Player A is about to serve and the score is 5-3, he is the one leading.

data.constraints:
[[PlayerA]] and [[PlayerB]] names can't contain whitespaces.
Input score will always be correct.
data.stubGenerator:
read playerA:word(10) playerB:word(10)
read scores:string(5)

write `LEADER IS player` OR `TIE` OR `player WON!!!`
`SERVER IS player` OR `SET ENDED`
data.inputDescription:
<<Line 1:>> Two space-separated strings [[PlayerA]] and [[PlayerB]]. PlayerA is always the first server.
<<Line 2:>> Two integers [[Score1]] and [[Score2]], separated by a dash.
data.outputDescription:
<<Line 1:>> One of the following:
- {{LEADER IS}}, followed by the name of the player who leads the set
- {{TIE}} if both players have the same score
- the name of the player who won, followed by {{WON!!!}}.
<<Line 2:>> One of the following:
- {{SERVER IS}} and the name of the player who is going to serve if the set is not ended
- {{SET ENDED}} otherwise

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

Marc is passionate about table tennis... but he often gets distracted when watching a match. He needs a tool that lets him tell who's leading the current set and who's going to serve on the next shot... or if the set is over.

In table tennis, the serve alternates between players every two points. So, the first player serves twice (regardless of the score), then their opponent serves twice, and so on. The first player to 11 points wins the set.
Be careful! If the players reach a score of 10-10, the serve alternates every point, and the winner is the first to be two points ahead of their opponent.

Regarding scoring, the score of the player who will serve next is always announced in front. If the set has already ended, this still applies: the first score announced is the score of the player who would serve next if the game were to continue.
For example, when Player A is about to serve and the score is 5-3, he is the one leading.
Input
Line 1: Two space-separated strings PlayerA and PlayerB. PlayerA is always the first server.
Line 2: Two integers Score1 and Score2, separated by a dash.
Output
Line 1: One of the following:
- LEADER IS, followed by the name of the player who leads the set
- TIE if both players have the same score
- the name of the player who won, followed by WON!!!.
Line 2: One of the following:
- SERVER IS and the name of the player who is going to serve if the set is not ended
- SET ENDED otherwise
Constraints
PlayerA and PlayerB names can't contain whitespaces.
Input score will always be correct.
Example
Input
PlayerA PlayerB
0-0
Output
TIE
SERVER IS PlayerA
